results.title: Brother
results.creator_credit: Takeshi Kitano, Masayuki Mori, Jeremy Thomas, Bac Films (France), Film Four International, Recorded Picture Company and Office Kitano
results.brief_description: Takeshi “Beat” Kitano went to the United States of America to film this cross-cultural gangster Yakuza film. Takeshi himself plays an exiled yakuza hitman who lands in Los Angeles with a bag of stolen money and resentful of his banishment from the home country. He finds his half-brother (Omar Epps) and together they attempt to take over the drug trade in Los Angeles. A return to highly kinetic crime fiction, “Brother” finds Takeshi Kitano in a much more playful mood after the personal reflections of “Hani-Bi”. Whipping furiously across the genre tropes of the gangster film and the Yakuza film, “Brother” emerges as a highly satisfying ride with deftly executed sequences of violence and warrior mayhem. The cultural differences between the two brothers - one being Japanese and the other being African-American - allows for some genuinely funny reflections on cultural and ethnic misunderstandings, but nothing allows the action to stop for a moment. In Japanese and English with English subtitles.

results.title: Bronco busters
results.creator_credit: Laurence Hyde and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Scenes of cowboys at the Calgary Stampede roping and riding wild horses captured from the ranges of Southern Alberta, Canada. The film also shows roping a calf, bull-dogging a steer, riding a bull, and a chuck-wagon race.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Laurence Hyde and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Brown men and red sand
results.creator_credit: C Mountford and South Australian Government Tourist Bureau
results.brief_description: This film is part of the original silent film record of C.P. Mountford’s Central Australian journey with a group of desert Aborigines. From the original footage the two popular sound films, “Walkabout” and “Tjurunga”, were compiled. “Brown men and red sand” (if projected at silent speed) shows the movements of the Aborigines, especially in the sequences dealing with tribal ceremonies and dances, more naturally than in the sound films, where the movements look jerky.

results.title: Broken journey: mending dreams
results.brief_description: A powerful and moving documentary about a family in search of itself. After 18 years in Australia, photographer Hanh Tran is making his first journey home to Vietnam. It’s a dream that has finally come true. Amidst the reunion of tears and laughter, an extraordinary family saga emerges. This film is not only a personal picture of Hanh and his family, but it also about life in contemporary Vietnam - a society in transition.

results.title: Broken English
results.creator_credit: Ned Lander, Rachel Perkins and City Pictures
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Blood brothers (A)”.
In 1958, as a result of a forced confession, an inability to read or write English and the racial intolerance of the police and the community of the time, Rupert Max Stuart, an indigenous Australian man, was sentenced to hang for the rape and murder of a nine year old girl. Using dramatisation, archival film and interviews with those involved, including Stuart himself, this video charts the trial, appeals and subsequent attempts to overthrow the conviction.

results.title: Brothers keeper [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Bruce Sinofsky, Joe Berlinger, American Playhouse Theatrical Films and Hand to Mouth Productions
results.brief_description: This award-winning documentary focuses on a controversial murder trial that took place in the Upstate New York farming community of Munnsville in 1990. 59 year old Delbert Ward, one of four reclusive, eccentric brothers who shared the same dilapidated two-room shack on their dairy farm for over 60 years, was accused of murder when his ailing older brother was found dead in the bed they shared. After being interrogated by the state police, the simple-minded and barely literate Delbert signed a confession stating that he smothered his brother as an act of mercy. Believing him incapable of murder, and not possessing the mental capacity to understand police bureaucracy, the local community rallied around Delbert and his brothers, raising bail in a matter of hours. The film covers the period between Delbert’s arrest and his trial, focusing on the daily lives of the ‘Ward boys’ as national media scrutiny intensifies around them. As the state police gather ‘evidence’ that incest was a motive for the killing, the local community’s support for the outcast Ward brothers strengthens. Interviews with state police and prosecuters, local residents and Delbert’s lawyer build the case for and against the accused. An intriguing, compelling and unashamedly subjective real-life murder mystery that goes beyond simply telling a good story to reveal the part the media plays in the formation of personal and community identity.

results.title: Freedom rides
results.creator_credit: Rachel Perkins, Ned Lander and City Pictures
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Blood brothers”.
Charles Perkins grew up in Alice Springs in a time when racial segregation was the rule. Sent away to Adelaide for an education he became increasingly aware of the injustices perpetrated against Australian First Nations peoples. In 1965 he instigated the “Freedom ride” - a busload of concerned people, mostly students - who visited outback Australia, notably Walgett and Moree, to escalate the level of public awareness of racial intolerance in Australia. This video documents that journey and talks to those who took part.

results.title: Brothers in trouble
results.creator_credit: Udayan Prasad, Robert Buckler, Renegade Films and BBC Film Unit
results.brief_description: This film presents an insightful look into the immigrant experience in Britain. Amir arrives illegally to England in the 1960’s. His arrival is less than grand, arriving in a vegetable crate, but he is willing to endure this indignity to find a better life than the one he had in India. His expectations are of wealth, opportunity and prosperity but instead he finds himself dissilusioned, sharing a house with seventeen other illegal immigrants in Northern England. They find themselves working in factories, no better off than the existence they left. Their lifestyle is punctuated by the comings and goings of agents, police informers, occasional enjoyable trips to the cinema to see Indian films and a weekly visit by a prostitute. Into their world arrives Mary, an illegal immigrant from Ireland that house leader Hussein Shah meets in a cafe. At first Mary brings hope and happiness to the household but when she announces that she is pregnant, traditional patriarch Hussein arranges a marriage of convenience between Mary and his nephew. Tension arises when the males of the household object to Mary’s free spirited ways. Starring Om Puri, Pavan Malhotra and Angeline Ball.

results.title: Jardiwarnpa: a Warlpiri fire ceremony
results.creator_credit: Ned Lander, Rachel Perkins, City Pictures, Warlpiri Media and Warlukurlangu Artists
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Blood brothers (A)”.
In order to combat the influence of western culture the elders of the Warlpiri people, led by Darby Jampijinpa Ross, a noted Aboriginal artist, decided to perform a fire ceremony which tells the story of Yarripiri’s journey. Yarripiri is both a real person and an incarnation of a dreamtime spirit. This video documents the preparations for the ceremony, the ceremony itself, the story the ceremony recreates and the problems the people have in performing it. Narrated by Kev Carmody.
